title: Persoonia prostrata
text:
Persoonia prostrata is a plant in the family <a href="Proteaceae">Proteaceae</a> and is <a href="Endemism">endemic</a> to the northern tip of <a href="K%27gari%20%28Fraser%20Island%29">K'gari</a> in <a href="Queensland">Queensland</a>, but is presumed to be extinct. It is similar to "<a href="Persoonia%20stradbrokensis">Persoonia stradbrokensis</a>" but is a <a href="prostrate%20shrub">prostrate shrub</a> with smaller leaves and flowers.
Description.
"Persoonia prostrata" is a prostrate shrub with elliptic to spatula-shaped leaves long and wide. The flowers are arranged along a <a href="Rachis%23In%20botany">rachis</a> up to long, that continues to grow after flowering, each flower with a scale leaf at its base. The <a href="tepal">tepal</a>s are about long. The species is only known from two collections and may be of a prostrate form of "<a href="Persoonia%20stradbrokensis">P. stradbrokensis</a>", although that species has not been found on K'gari.
Taxonomy.
"Persoonia prostrata" was first formally described in 1810 by <a href="Robert%20Brown%20%28botanist%2C%20born%201773%29">Robert Brown</a> in "<a href="Linnean%20Society%20of%20London%23Publications">Transactions of the Linnean Society of London</a>" from specimens he collected near the coast of <a href="Sandy%20Cape">Sandy Cape</a> in 1802.
Distribution and habitat.
This geebung is only known from the Brown's <a href="Type%20%28biology%29">type</a> collection and another collected near the end of the 19th century, both from Sandy Cape on K'gari, where it grew on <a href="Dune">sand dunes</a> in <a href="heath">heath</a>, <a href="woodland">woodland</a> or <a href="forest">forest</a>.
Conservation status.
"Persoonia prostrata" is classified as "extinct" under the Australian Government "<a href="Environment%20Protection%20and%20Biodiversity%20Conservation%20Act%201999">Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999</a>" and the Queensland Government "<a href="Nature%20Conservation%20Act%201992">Nature Conservation Act 1992</a>".
